note.p: A letter from sir Wilfrid Bliss Spender (1876-1960) to his wife, Lady Lillian Spender, n√©e Dean, (1880-1968). In this letter Spender writes of a row he has had with the General Officer Commanding following the GOC's discovery that one of Spender's letters had been published (without Spender's consent). Spender describes the fallout from this discovery in detail, relating it to his strained relationships with some of the other staff, and his growing anxiety about the future.

Sir Wilfrid Spender was a member of the British Army until 1913 when controversy surrounding his signature of the Ulster Solemn League and Covenant resulted in his resignation. Spender was called up for military service in 1914 and from 1915 served in the 36th (Ulster) Division. Throughout the war, Spender wrote a collection of letters to his wife Lady Lillian Spender. The letters date mainly from 1915 to 1918, when Sir Wilfrid was serving in France. The letters concern politics, the Irish question, personal life, and Wilfrid's experience of the Great War. Lady Lillian served in the Ulster Volunteer Nursing Corps during the war, and was an organiser of the Ulster Division Comforts Fund.

body.p:
I have just had a
d of a row. Either Gen' P
or Sir G published the letter
I sent them, in which the
abbreviated version is "the GOC
now confesses he has got
excellent troops". He is perfect
-ly furious & swears all
kind of threats. I can quite
see his point of view in
this as it makes an impli-
cation - not intended that he
did not appreciate them
before, & he thinks I have
been criticising him behind
his back. I find it a little
hard to forgive Sir G who
I suspect is the culprit &
who as a soldier ought
to have known better.

I have saved Farnham
& Singleton by getting Henry
to suppress his paper in
which letters written by
them appear. It is rather
like the b w's luck &
you will not even see my
name mentioned in conse-
quence —- in fact the fuss
is not yet over. The G never
forgives & we at present
loathe the sight of each-
other, tho I do see his
point of view.

You may as well be very
careful in your dealings
with Mrs & all who are
likely to pass on things to her.
I rather wish I was going
to the 24 Div tomorrow to
get things over as the atmos
phere is sultry & P does
not help much- au contraire
he is coming by his own &
will make the most of it.

Well thank goodness I
shan't be a soldier after
the war is over, & tho I
suppose roses will be
forbidden the the state,
perhaps a cabbage rose
or 2 may be allowed.

As luck will have it
there is no letter today
from you, but I had 2
yesterday, only today it
would just have been
extra appreciated.

17th I am out this morning
writing in the open which would be
rather jolly but for the flies, which
in the absence of flypaper , or p v
or other convenient substitutes are
troublesome. I fancy I am now
on the Gen's nerves like Russell
&Graig in which case it may
be as well if I leave which is
what I think he has in mind.
In many ways I shall not
regret it as there are disad-
vantages in being with "ones"
own children" in a battle &
I quite see them. At the
same time it will be a bit
of a wrench & will be one
of the other things which
one will not be able to
explain after the war, tho'
perhaps then - but not now -
I shall drop a hint to Craig
of how it has happened.

Poor old Sir G he would be
sorry if he knew, & would proba-
bly do something even worse such
as write to the G or get Carson to
do so, which would be too awful.

You know the kind of feeling
of silent sorrow when one
little boy has been naughty,
the atmosphere is like that
now, & I believe the culprit
is the only one who does not
"appear" to appreciate it. All the
others except Comyn & the G are dining
out , & hints have been given
by Place which I'm
hanged if I will take. I've
had far too many smacks in
the past to run away from
another now & can devise
quite a lot of fun out of
the complex situation.

Every one here seems fairly
comfortable & Rex may I hope
settle in next week, but I can-
not tell you what an anxiety
his arrival is especially as one
is helpless to give him any aid,
& I should only make a mess of
it if I tried - as has happened
before.

However there are great
advantages in all these unpleas-
antness, undoubtedly the b w
who would have miffed at any
ordinary b w law will now
be content with the most secluded
& diminutive rabbit hutch, provided
the p v is satisfied to live in
it. Of the war news you know
more than I do. It begins to
bore me !

I hope this week will not be
too strenuous for a p v. Remember
bw it is her business to keep
fit not only for her work but
also for the sake of that very
unsatisfactory tho rather
affectionate animal
